abstracts.cdata!:
This Indigenous Peoples Development Plan
            for the Third AIDS Project for Brazil identifies the tribal
            groups in urban and border areas who are most vulnerable to
            HIV/AIDS; the major tendencies and characteristics of the
            AIDS epidemic ; external and internal factors for increasing
            risk and vulnerability and the government's response;
            access to preventive, diagnostic and treatment services for
            indigenous peoples; and then against that backdrop, the
            report outlines the plan of action. The action plan aims to
            1) improve the local management process and encourage the
            programming of joint actions by the Special Indigenous
            Health District (DSEI) and local std/aids administrators; 2)
            mobilize additional human and technical resources to train
            DSEI health teams; 3) strengthen the task force to monitor
            the establishment of STD/AIDS programs within the DSEIs; 4)
            prioritize prevention and treatment measures aimed at
            members of the indigenous population living in urban areas,
            through strategic measures coordinated with state and
            municipal authorities and nongovernmental organizations; 5)
            establish a joint plan for assistance measures; and 6)
            establish instruments to match, at the local level,
            information collected by the Indigenous Health Care
            Information System and the Reportable Diseases Information
            System to reduce under-reporting of cases. The IPP supports
            behavior modification projects and health campaigns;
            organizes macro-regional meetings to define prevention
            strategies, promotes social monitoring, and mobilizes
            indigenous peoples; provides basic and advanced training of
            indigenous agents and Indian schoolteachers as information
            disseminators; trains medical staff; conducts
            zero-prevalence studies in selected sites to identify the
            risk situation and exposure; and produces technical
            documentation and instructional material.
